segments.pli: Atha kho somā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then the nun Somā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

segments.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
segments.en: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Dark Forest,

segments.pli: Andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā somāya bhikkhuniyā bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo yena somā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā somaṃ bhikkhuniṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Somā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:
it’s for the sages to attain.
It’s not possible for a woman,

segments.pli: “ko nu khvāyaṃ manusso vā amanusso vā gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti?
segments.en: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”

segments.pli: “māro kho ayaṃ pāpimā mama bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti.
segments.en: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”

segments.pli: Atha kho somā bhikkhunī “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi paccabhāsi:
segments.en: Then Somā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
as you rightly discern the Dhamma.
is fit for Māra to address.”

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ somā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Somā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

suttaplex.blurb: When meditating in the Dark Wood, the nun Somā is taunted by Māra, who claims that a mere woman can never see the subtle truth. She rejects him, stating that gender does not matter when one is perceiving deep truths, and telling Māra to go see those still attached to gender.
